Joseph Goebbels resented the work of the Sonderdienst Seehaus when it was taken up in 1940 because it reported to Joachim von Ribbentropp’s Foreign Ministry and not his own department. He was also convinced that only a few trusted individuals should be allowed to listen to foreign radio stations. Allowing access to more people, he believed, was potentially damaging for public morale

title: The Year of Climax

The following year the BBC Year Book 1946 also stated that “the BBC projects Britain by way of commentaries on Parliamentary debates, reviews of the British Press, and talks by political and other representatives of British opinion and outlook.” Other transmissions are “devoted to British science, literature, music, stage, film, and sport.” The same article notes that the “English by Radio” broadcasts “have proved to be the most popular transmissions of the European Services. Evidence reaches the BBC from all parts of Europe that the English lessons broadcast [...] are welcomed by an ever-growing audience anxious to learn English or to improve their knowledge of it for cultural and economic purposes
